oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Columbia Union Station Depot: east view of rear of building
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eatherly, Brad, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of the rear of a train station viewed from the east. The rail (south) elevation of the west wing includes a double-leaf doorway with wood-and-glass doors. A two-light transom caps the doorway. Three one-over-one double hung sash windows are located on the west wing. The first floor of the main structure's south elevation includes a double-leaf wood-and-glass doorway, a single-leaf wood doorway, and a second double-leaf wood-and-glass doorway. Each doorway is capped with a three light semi-circular transom window with traceried muntins. The second floor of the main structure includes seven one-over-one double-hung sash windows topped by eight small fixed single light attic windows. The main structure's east elevation includes a single one-over one double-hung sash window, three small fixed single light attic windows, and a tall stone chimney with four flues and a corbeled top. The east wing's (foreground) south elevation has three one-over-one double hung sash windows.

The Columbia Union Station train depot was built from 1902-1905 by the Nashville, Chattanooga, and St. Louis Railway and the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. It operated as a passenger service depot until 1954 when airline travel became more popular and as a freight depot until 1961, at which time it became unused as a station. The building served as an apartment complex in the 1970s and 1980s until it fell into disrepair. It was restored in the early 2010s.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Railroad stations
